official-title.#text:
To expand the Federal Funding Accountability and
		  Transparency Act of 2006 to increase accountability and transparency in Federal
		  spending, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Oversight and Government
			 Reform

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the
			 following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Digital Accountability and
			 Transparency Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.

Sec. 3. Amendments to the Federal Funding Accountability and
				Transparency Act of 2006.

Sec. 4. Pilot program to evaluate consolidated recipient
				reporting.

Sec. 6. American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009
				amendments.

Sec. 7. Disaster Relief Appropriations Act of 2013
				amendments.

Sec. 8. Executive agency accounting and other financial
				management reports and plans.

text.#text: The purposes of this Act are to—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
by disclosing direct
			 Federal agency expenditures and linking Federal contract, loan, and grant
			 spending information to programs of Federal agencies in order to enable
			 taxpayers and policymakers to track Federal spending more effectively;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Federal
			 Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006

text.#text:
simplify reporting
			 for entities receiving Federal funds by streamlining reporting requirements and
			 reducing compliance costs while improving transparency; and

improve the
			 quality of data submitted to USASpending.gov by holding Federal agencies
			 accountable for the completeness and accuracy of the data submitted.

header.#text:
Department of
				the treasury requirements for data standards

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Office of Management and Budget

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and the heads of Federal agencies, shall establish Government-wide
				financial data standards for Federal funds, which shall—

text.#text:
include common
				data elements, such as codes, unique award identifiers, and fields, for
				financial and payment information required to be reported by Federal agencies
				and entities receiving Federal funds, including identifiers for Federal awards
				and entities receiving Federal awards;

to the extent
				reasonable and practicable, ensure interoperability and incorporate—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, such as the
				International Organization for Standardization;

text.#text:
common data
				elements developed and maintained by an international voluntary consensus
				standards body, as defined by the

common data
				elements developed and maintained by Federal agencies with authority over
				contracting and financial assistance, such as the Federal Acquisition
				Regulatory Council; and

are consistent
				with and implement applicable accounting principles;

are capable of
				being continually upgraded as necessary;

are structured to
				specifically support the reporting of financial and performance-related data,
				such as that any data produced, regardless of reporting need or software used
				for creation or consumption, is consistent and comparable across reporting
				situations;

establish, for
				each data point, a standard method of conveying the reporting period, reporting
				entity, unit of measure, and other associated attributes; and
